reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of urgently needed life-saving drugs and medical consumables for women and children in Gaza, especially those affected by events in early 2018

description.narrative: This project will enable UNICEF to provide urgent support to the health sector to respond to humanitarian needs of the most vulnerable pregnant and lactating women and children in Gaza in the current context of mass demonstrations. The OCHA funding will specifically be used to respond to the key components of the health sector emergency response, namely to ensure access to healthcare for emergency patients particularly pregnant and lactating women and children, and to contribute to the enhancement of the trauma pathway by decreasing risk of death and disability amongst injured cases. The total number of women and children that will benefit from the OCHA funding will be 89,042, across the Gaza Strip over a twelve-month period. It is estimated that 27,604 high risk women and 61,438 children (60% off boys and 40% of girls) will benefit from urgently needed lifesaving health interventions. In coordination with MOH and the Health cluster, UNICEF will procure essential drugs and medical supplies to the MoH hospitals and clinics (six Neonatal Intensive Care Units-NICUs, five maternity and paediatric hospitals and clinics), and will primarily address the immediate health needs of vulnerable women and children that are currently being neglected as a result of the burden on the health sector caused by the increased casualties. Additionally, in coordination with the Disability sub-group and CBOs, UNICEF will procure the assistive devices (100 wheelchairs and 150 crutches) to children who are suffering from event related and trauma caused disabilities and will ensure referrals to psychosocial support services delivered by the Family Centres. This support will alleviate some of the burden of the trauma injuries and increased casualties on the health system, and will allow the health facilities to respond to the emergency needs of high risk women and young children. Therefore, the project will address critical gaps in the health sector response for vulnerable women and children in Gaza including the needs for assistive devices of children who are suffering from trauma caused disabilities.
